posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked:
I am looking for ways to make hot-swappable arms for an FTC mascot bot. What I mean by this is I want to have different arms for different tasks so that the arms would have different things on them, such as different amounts of motors, servos, and sensors. I would want the arm to be able to rotate at the attachment point (or what would be the shoulder of the mascot bot).  
EDIT: If this is not possible, it’s fine. I just wanted to know if anyone else has tried or done this.

If you're looking for truly hot-swappable systems—ones that operate through a teleoperated program started—this could be extremely challenging, though still feasible. In the past, we've used swappable mechanisms, but these were typically performed between matches when the robot was shut down. Could you clarify your specific objective?

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked:
The robot would simply be turned off.  
I aim to create a system where the main body stays intact while interchangeable arms can be used for various components.  
I plan on switching between different programs depending on the task.

That essentially boils down to configuration. If you have an extra motor port available, set up another motor wire to where you're making the swap, and ensure programmers, drivers, or pit crew have a written checklist detailing which programs require specific motors in designated ports. If fully utilizing all motor ports with both load configurations, tracking becomes more challenging but remains achievable.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: Sure, you'd just run wire extensions from the attachment point, each labeled appropriately. As for multiple expansion hubs, yes, it is indeed possible.

You’d only run extra motor wires if you have unused ports. If you've already used all available ports, swapping mechanisms may use the same wires. It’s simpler to assign fixed ports, such as the first load to port 1 and the second to port 2. The complexity of your swapping mechanisms will affect how challenging it is.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: Okay, thank you for all of your help!

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: You can believe adding multiple expansion hubs. Legally in competition, I think it's two. For your purposes, that doesn’t really matter.

From a competition standpoint, you are limited to one control hub and one expansion hub (or one Android phone and one expansion hub). In a demonstration scenario, I am unsure if configuring a second hub is feasible. Additionally, having eight motors across two hubs already imposes a significant strain on the battery life, and running nine or more motors would further accelerate the depletion of battery capacity.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: Well, for me, issues like that don't really matter because of the application. I did some calculations, and all the time, there are at least seven motor ports in use. If I were to use motors on the arms, I would need additional ports.

OK. I will ping my programmer to see if he knows how to configure a second expansion hub. On the other hand, it might be simpler to stick with just the two hubs and use separate programs with their own configuration files. This would require more attention to ensure everything stays synced between the coders, builders, and drivers.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: the coders and builders and drivers I am all of the above
An alternative to additional expansion hubs, if you aren't using all of the servo ports and you don't need encoder feedback from all of the motors, is to use SparkMini motor controllers.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: So if I used this would I need to address it as CRservo in the code
